description:
In this talk, you’ll learn how the CPAN process works and how you can harness that. Part of the talk will demonstrate the current state of DPAN, the tools that let you make your own CPAN, and some of it will talk about the continuing development of these tools.

CPAN is Perl’s killer feature, but it’s also risky. CPAN tools always want to install the latest versions of everything, but you might not want to spend most of your development time resolving upgrade issues. CPAN versions overwrite local bug fixes. CPAN Authors can remove distributions that you depend on. Other people might not patch their code as quickly as you need the fixes. When you use CPAN, you tie the health of your application to a network of third-party programmers you don’t control and may not be thinking about your interests.

The CPAN tools don’t care where you get your distributions, so you can create your own CPAN repository without giving up the tools. That’s where “DPAN”, the (Distributed|Dark|Decentralized)PAN reduces your risk. Put all of the distributions you want to use in a directory, run the dpan script, and then point the same CPAN tools at the repository it created for you.

Since it’s your repository, you manage it however you like. You can even create multiple DPAN repositories, one per project if you like. With a stable repository, you can focus on the work that matters to you rather than managing external code.
title: Reduce your Risk by Creating your Own CPAN
